item.title: Pro-EU Mayor Takes Slim Lead in Poland Vote, Exit Polls Show
item.description: The centrist mayor of Warsaw took a slim lead in Poland’s presidential election over a nationalist candidate backed by Donald Trump, giving a boost to the country’s pro-European Union government, exit polls show.
item.dc:creator: Wojciech Moskwa, Natalia Ojewska

media:content.media:description: Rafal Trzaskowski and his wife Malgorzata Trzaskowska, during an election night rally in Warsaw, Poland, on Sunday, June 1, 2025.

item.title: Summers, Bernanke Recall Fischer as Brilliant Economic Scholar
item.description: Stanley Fischer was remembered Sunday as a mentor to economic luminaries around the world.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Liao

media:content.media:description: Stanley Fischer, former vice chairman of the U.S. Federal Reserve.

item.title: Stanley Fischer, Who Spread Macroeconomic Gospel, Dies at 81
item.description: Stanley Fischer, a professor and practitioner of macroeconomics who helped guide central banks in two countries, Israel and the US, and mentored a younger generation of economic decision-makers, has died. He was 81.
item.dc:creator: Laurence Arnold, Alisa Odenheimer

item.title: Trump’s Steel Tariffs ‘Economic Self Harm,’ Australian PM Says
item.description: Donald Trump’s decision to double steel tariffs on imports was “inappropriate” but it won’t impact Australia any more than it would other countries, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said.
item.dc:creator: Chelsea Mes

media:content.media:description: Scrap metal heated in a steel furnace at BlueScope Steel Ltd. Port Kembla steelworks in Port Kembla, Australia, on Friday, Feb. 9, 2024. The world's two biggest miners, BHP Group Ltd. and Rio Tinto Group, are teaming up in a bid to develop Australia's first electric-smelting furnace, in what could prove an important step toward slashing emissions in the steel-making process.

item.title: China Home Sales Slump Drags On as Deflation Eats Into Incomes
item.description: China’s residential property sales continued to fall on in May, signaling the real estate slump is still weighing on an economy that’s under pressure from deflation and trade tensions.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Zhu, Emma Dong

media:content.media:description: Residential buildings under construction at the China Vanke Co. Elegant Lifestyle project in Shenzhen, China, on Wednesday, April 17, 2024.

item.title: US Job Growth Is Seen Moderating on Shifting Trade Policy
item.description: The pace of US hiring probably slowed in May, with employers focusing on containing costs as households become a bit more guarded and businesses reconsidered investment plans against a backdrop of shifting trade policy.
item.dc:creator: Vince Golle, Craig Stirling

media:content.media:description: Commuters board a Red line Metro train at the Metro Center metro stop in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, May 30, 2025. A House Republican introduced legislation to block federal funding for the Washington Metrorail system unless it is renamed the "Trump Train," Axios reports.

item.title: South Korea’s Exports Drop on Tariff and Political Risks
item.description: South Korea’s exports contracted in May, underscoring growing challenges for the trade-reliant economy as global demand weakens and uncertainties deepen over Donald Trump’s sweeping tariff push.
item.dc:creator: Heesu Lee, Myungshin Cho

item.title: BOE’s Breeden Believes UK Labor Market Loosening: Sunday Times
item.description: Bank of England’s Sarah Breeden believes the UK labor market is loosening, while she sees “waves of disinflation” continuing, according to an interview the central bank deputy governor for financial stability gave to Sunday Times.
item.dc:creator: Yi Wei Wong

item.title: Confidence Among UK Directors Rebounds to Pre-Budget High
item.description: UK business confidence has recovered to levels last seen before Labour’s budget in October as investment intentions pick up but lingering fears of a global downturn continue to weigh on sentiment, according to the Institute of Directors.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick

media:content.media:description: Visitors at a viewing spot overlooking the Canary Wharf financial, business and shopping district in London, UK, on Tuesday, Aug. 20, 2024. Hundreds of financial firms are struggling to comply with a new UK regime designed to rein in online payment scams before an Oct. 7 deadline after one of the worst summers for fraud.

item.title: Thousands Rally in Bulgaria to Protest Plan for Euro Adoption
item.description: Thousands of people gathered in dozens of cities across Bulgaria to protest against the adoption of the euro as authorities prepare to switch to the European Union’s single currency early next year.
item.dc:creator: Slav Okov

media:content.media:description: A demonstration against Bulgaria entering the Eurozone in Sofia on May 31.

item.title: Russian Assets Deserve Closer Look, German Official Tells FAS
item.description: The European Union should revisit the question of how hundreds of billions of euros in frozen Russian assets can be used to finance Ukraine, a top German official said.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Weber

media:content.media:description: The golden domes of the Kremlin's churches and cathedrals sit in Moscow, Russia, on Sunday, May 27, 2018. President Vladimir Putin told executives from foreign companies that Russia won’t punish its international partners for compliance with anti-Russian sanctions, spokesman Dmitry Peskov said by phone. Photographer: Andrey Rudakov/Bloomberg

item.title: Stablecoin Regulation Could Shakeup US Financial System
item.description: The Trump administration touts deregulation as a source of economic growth — the thinking is that removing what it sees as shackles on business will promote it. But sometimes it takes regulation to do that.
item.dc:creator: Chris Anstey

media:content.media:description: An illustration picture taken in London on May 8, 2022, shows a gold plated souvenir cryptocurrency Tether (USDT) coin arranged beside a screen displaying US dollar notes. Tether (USDT) is an Ethereum token known as a stablecoin that is pegged to the value of the US dollar, and is currently the largest stablecoin with a market value of USD 83 billion dollars. (Photo by Justin TALLIS / AFP) (Photo by JUSTIN TALLIS/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Thailand’s $115 Billion Budget Clears First Parliamentary Hurdle
item.description: Thailand’s lower house of parliament backed a 3.78 trillion baht ($115 billion) annual budget as Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra’s multi-party coalition buried differences to support the spending plan.
item.dc:creator: Suttinee Yuvejwattana

media:content.media:description: This aerial photo shows vehicles driving along a highway between Khlong Toei slum (L) and high-rise buildings (R) in Bangkok on May 20, 2025.

item.title: Charting the Global Economy: US GDP Falls on Larger Trade Hit
item.description: The US economy contracted slightly to start the year, largely reflecting a bigger tariff-related trade hit but also a larger downshift in household spending growth than first estimated.
item.dc:creator: Vince Golle, Molly Smith

media:content.media:description: Cranes at the Port of Seattle behind a pier at the Waterfront in Seattle, Washington, US, on Wednesday, May 28, 2025. The Bureau of Economic Analysis is scheduled to release gross domestic product (GDP) figures on May 29.

item.title: How Do We Define a Currency?
item.dc:creator: Joe Weisenthal, Tracy Alloway

item.title: ECB Officials Ready to Keep Working With Convicted Colleague
item.description: European Central Bank policymakers are prepared to keep working with their colleague Peter Kazimir despite his conviction for bribery this week, according to people familiar with their thinking.
item.dc:creator: Jana Randow, Jan Bratanic, Jasmina Kuzmanovic

media:content.media:description: Peter Kazimir, governor of the National Bank of Slovakia and governing council member of the European Central Bank (ECB), at the Bank of Korea International Conference in Seoul, South Korea, on Thursday, May 30, 2024. The ECB last month bolstered expectations that interest rates will be cut in June as inflation recedes.

item.title: China’s Factory Activity Contraction Eases After Trade War Truce
item.description: China’s factory activity contracted at a slower rate in May after a reprieve in the tariff war with the US unclogged trade flows, even as weak domestic demand continues to weigh on the economy.
item.dc:creator: Lucille Liu

media:content.media:description: An employee on the body shop floor at the Zeekr Group Intelligent Factory in Ningbo, China, on Tuesday, April 29, 2025. Geely Automobile Holdings Ltd., China's fourth-ranked carmaker by market share, said last month that its AI-powered pilot system will be added to all of its brands, including Galaxy, Zeekr and Lynk&Co. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: Fed’s Daly Says Still Comfortable With Two Rate Cuts in 2025
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco President Mary Daly said she was still comfortable with projections the Fed released in March showing officials expect to lower interest rates twice before the end of the year.
item.dc:creator: Jonnelle Marte

media:content.media:description: San Francisco Fed President Mary Daly

item.title: Moody’s Cuts Brazil Outlook, Delivering Fiscal Warning to Lula
item.description: Moody’s Ratings lowered Brazil’s credit outlook to stable from positive, delivering a reproof to President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva’s government at a time when it is under increasing pressure to shore up the country’s fiscal situation.
item.dc:creator: Vinicius Andrade, Giovanna Bellotti Azevedo, Martha Viotti Beck
